Class of 2020,

Warren Bennis, a renowned scholar on leadership, said, “Becoming a leader is synonymous with becoming yourself. It is precisely that simple and it is also that difficult.” As a class you have worked hard at becoming yourselves in spite of the history swirling around you.

You have shown to this community, to your parents, to your teachers, and to each other that you are capable, bright, beautiful, and compassionate young leaders who will enter the next phase of your life ready to serve and eager to build a better future.

On behalf of all of us at Newcastle Public Schools, I wish you only joy on your journey to becoming more of yourself. You have proven you can meet challenges head on and remain focused on your dreams. Racer spirit goes with you wherever you go, and we will always be proud to see you when you come home.

Go Racers!

Melonie Hau

NPS takes the health and safety of our students and staff very seriously and wants to do everything we can to limit the spread of illness. We are working closely with our custodial team to ensure all common areas such as door handles, drinking fountains, and other hard surfaces are wiped down and thoroughly sanitized on a routine, consistent basis.

District staff are and will continue to monitor the number of illnesses reported per building. If parents and guardians are calling in their student as absent and ill, they are encouraged to provide specific information, if possible.

--Everyday tips to prevent the spread of germs:
--Cover your nose and mouth when you cough or sneeze
--Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds
--If your child is sick, please keep them at home for at least 24 hours after fever is gone without the use of fever-reducing medication

Newcastle High School administration became aware late this afternoon of a rumored hit list containing names of Newcastle students. The Newcastle Police Department was notified of the rumored list and are investigating the situation.

Newcastle Schools has safety procedures in place to address these types of threats and parents have been notified. As an additional precautionary measure, NPS will have an increased presence of law enforcement on campus at the bonfire this evening and on campus Thursday.

We encourage parents and our community to report any suspected threats to school administration or the Newcastle Police Department. In addition, we encourage parents and students to utilize the STOP IT app which can be accessed on the district web page. The safety of our students is of our upmost concern. We will continue to notify parents if additional precautions are needed.

Thank you in advance for your cooperation as we work together to ensure the safest environment for our students, staff and community.

As we learn more about the audit we will continue to keep you updated.
The Board of Education and Administration have nothing to hide and look forward to putting this behind us as we continue to focus on providing the best academic environment for all of our students.

Best,
Kristi Ferguson
Interim Superintendent

Jordan Shepard, incoming Newcastle High School junior and Future Farmers of America, Vice President and Carsten Kates, Newcastle High School senior and FFA Treasurer were chosen to attend the Washington Leadership Conference for FFA students from around the country.

In addition to seeing historical sites the students learned about diversity in communities, created a Living to Serve plan designed to help make their community better and stronger.

An evening event exposed the students to the different socio-economic classes through dining out as an a person who comes from an upper, middle or lower class. The following day students packaged oatmeal for people in need.

Student lessons learned: Do what you can, with what you have, where you are!
